title: Hazardous material in a single-room house
vignette: Toxic substances are present inside a small home with one doorway.

options.text: The doorway becomes contaminated; anything exiting there requires decontamination.
Contamination spreads only within, not through the door.

title: Tree canopy over a contaminated site
vignette: People gather under branches that overhang a contaminated area.

options.text: They face exposure risk because airborne contaminants can accumulate under the canopy.
Open-air branches do not concentrate contaminants significantly.

title: Shared roof with partial wall
vignette: A roof extends over two rooms separated only by a partial divider. Hazardous material is on one side.

options.text: Both sides face contamination risk under the same ventilation system.
The divider provides adequate separation; other room remains safe.

title: Covering hazardous material with a board
vignette: To move contaminated waste, they slide a wooden board on top and lift it.

options.text: The board becomes contaminated through direct contact.
Temporary covering with proper protection prevents contamination.

title: Loft directly above a contaminated site
vignette: An apartment is built above an old toxic waste dump.

options.text: Living there poses health risks through ground contamination.
Separate floors and proper foundations block contamination from rising.

title: Hazardous transport passing under an archway
vignette: A truck carrying toxic materials drives beneath a stone arch.

options.text: Anyone beneath the arch faces exposure risk during transport.
Only those in direct contact with the materials face risk.

title: Room with multiple openings containing hazardous material
vignette: Toxic substances are present in a room that has two doors and a window.

options.text: All openings require monitoring unless one is designated for containment.
Only the opening used for removal needs special protocols.

title: Stacked containers over contaminated material
vignette: Boxes are piled above hazardous waste resting on the ground.

options.text: Everything above becomes contaminated through the stack.
Only the lowest container directly touching is contaminated.

title: Hazardous material transported in a wagon
vignette: The wagon passes beneath a bridge while people stand atop it.

options.text: Those on the bridge face exposure due to proximity and air circulation.
The bridge counts as a separate structure; they remain safe.

title: Partially contained hazardous material
vignette: Part of contaminated material extends outside the containment area.

options.text: Entire area and access points require decontamination protocols.
Only the portion inside the containment area poses risk.

title: Portable canopy for protection during cleanup
vignette: Workers hold a fabric canopy over themselves near the contaminated site.

options.text: They face increased exposure risk under the same cover.
A moving canopy does not create containment issues.

title: Entering a treehouse with contaminated material below
vignette: Hazardous waste lies on the ground beneath a treehouse used by children.

options.text: Airborne contaminants can rise; the treehouse poses risk.
Elevation above open air provides adequate protection.

title: Doorway sealed after contamination
vignette: After contamination in the room, one doorway is closed off with barriers.

options.text: Sealing prevents contamination from spreading through that opening.
Once contamination occurred, it already spread; sealing is ineffective.

title: Hazardous material in a container aboard a ship
vignette: A sealed container holds toxic substances on deck while passengers sleep below.

options.text: Ship's cabins remain safe if the container is properly sealed.
Contamination can leak and affect the whole vessel.

title: Small contaminated fragment under a shared roof
vignette: A tiny piece of contaminated material is discovered under the eaves where neighbors gather.

options.text: Any amount of contaminated material poses risk under the roof.
Fragments smaller than threshold amounts are negligible.
